for N-nitroso nortriptyline based on the TD50 of 0.008 mg/kg/day for N-nitroso methylphenethyl
amine. However, our findings raise a question about the appropriateness
of such a low AI limit for this particular NDSRI, given its relatively
low α-hydroxylation value of only 0.07, in comparison to the
higher values observed for the three analogues, including N-nitroso methylphenethyl amine. Despite experimental
evidence indicating that the primary clearance pathway for the selective
serotonin reuptake inhibitor paroxetine involves metabolic modification
of the 1,3-benzdioxole ring and that no metabolites resulting from
α-carbon hydroxylation after a possible nitrosation of the piperidine
ring were observed in humans,23 we conducted
this case study to evaluate the potential carcinogenicity of N-nitroso paroxetine to account for the theoretical possibility
of its introduction via external sources, e.g., as an impurity. Specifically,
we aimed to compare its α-hydroxylation potential with that
of three structurally related analogues (Figure 10). Application of α-hydroxylation computation
on N-nitroso paroxetine and its structurally similar
analogues. α-CH2 groups are shown with orange circles
(Pα-hydrox—computed
probability of α-hydroxylation). Our results revealed that N-nitroso
paroxetine
exhibited a significantly higher α-hydroxylation potential of
0.86 than two of its analogues, nitrosopiperdinol (0.61) and nitrosopiperidine
(0.56). Conversely, 1-nitroso-3-pyrrolidinol, the third analogue,
demonstrated a slightly higher hydroxylation potential (0.78) than
the other two analogues; however, its 5-membered ring structure, which
is more constrained, may explain its higher TD50 value.
Given the potential risks associated with nitrosamine impurities where
utmost caution is warranted, utilizing these analogues to establish
AI level for N-nitroso paroxetine is inadvisable.
Additional investigations are imperative to explore alternative methods
for assessing the safety of N-nitroso paroxetine.

In this study,
we applied the calculation of the likelihood of α-hydroxylation
to the N-nitroso derivative of varenicline and three
related N-nitrosamine analogues (NPIP, NHEX, and
NTHP) with available carcinogenicity data (Figure 8). The analogues are taken from a recent
publication by Ponting et al.23 The predicted
hydroxylation values for N-nitroso varenicline, NPIP,
and NHEX were 0.63, 0.56, and 0.56, respectively. Notably, the hydroxylation
values for NPIP and NHEX were identical despite their differing ring
sizes due to our modeling process treating rings of size 5–8
equally. Application of α-hydroxylation computation on N-nitroso varenicline and its structurally similar analogues for establishing
a daily AI limit. α-CH2 groups are shown with orange
circles (Pα-hydrox—computed probability of α-hydroxylation
and NC—not calculated due to the presence of uncovered fragments). The AI limit for N-nitroso varenicline
has been
set at 37 ng/day by several regulatory agencies, who have used NTHP
as a surrogate to determine the appropriate threshold.53−55 However, the α-hydroxylation value for NTHP could not be reliably
calculated due to the presence of “uncovered fragments”
near the nitrosamine moiety resulting from the presence of unsaturation
in the ring, indicating its structural dissimilarity to N-nitroso varenicline, NPIP, and NHEX. Conversely, NPIP and NHEX exhibited
hydroxylation values comparable to N-nitroso varenicline
and are deemed suitable surrogates for deriving the AI limit, consistent
with the opinion of Ponting et al. As a conservative measure, we can
select NHEX as the surrogate for AI derivation. According to Ponting
et al.,23 the AI limit was established
as 110 ng/day using the TD50 of NHEX from the most sensitive
tumorigenic site (TD50 = 0.110 mg/kg/day).

In this study,
we aimed to assess the potential carcinogenicity of N-nitroso nortriptyline by comparing its α-hydroxylation potential
with that of the three structurally related analogues identified by
the QSAR Flex software program (Figure 9). QSAR Flex utilizes a database of small nitrosamines with carcinogenicity data
to match different atom types around the nitrosamine moiety for identifying
suitable analogues. Application of α-hydroxylation computation on N-nitroso nortriptyline and its structurally similar analogues.
α-CH2 groups are shown with orange circles (Pα-hydrox—computed
probability of α-hydroxylation). It is noteworthy that several regulatory agencies,
including Health
Canada55 and the EMA,54 have established an extremely low AI limit of 8 ng/day
for N-nitroso nortriptyline based on the TD50 of 0.008 mg/kg/day for N-nitroso methylphenethyl
amine. However, our findings raise a question about the appropriateness
of such a low AI limit for this particular NDSRI, given its relatively
low α-hydroxylation value of only 0.07, in comparison to the
higher values observed for the three analogues, including N-nitroso methylphenethyl amine.

Despite experimental
evidence indicating that the primary clearance pathway for the selective
serotonin reuptake inhibitor paroxetine involves metabolic modification
of the 1,3-benzdioxole ring and that no metabolites resulting from
α-carbon hydroxylation after a possible nitrosation of the piperidine
ring were observed in humans,23 we conducted
this case study to evaluate the potential carcinogenicity of N-nitroso paroxetine to account for the theoretical possibility
of its introduction via external sources, e.g., as an impurity. Specifically,
we aimed to compare its α-hydroxylation potential with that
of three structurally related analogues (Figure 10). Application of α-hydroxylation computation
on N-nitroso paroxetine and its structurally similar
analogues. α-CH2 groups are shown with orange circles
(Pα-hydrox—computed
probability of α-hydroxylation). Our results revealed that N-nitroso
paroxetine
exhibited a significantly higher α-hydroxylation potential of
0.86 than two of its analogues, nitrosopiperdinol (0.61) and nitrosopiperidine
(0.56). Conversely, 1-nitroso-3-pyrrolidinol, the third analogue,
demonstrated a slightly higher hydroxylation potential (0.78) than
the other two analogues; however, its 5-membered ring structure, which
is more constrained, may explain its higher TD50 value.
Given the potential risks associated with nitrosamine impurities where
utmost caution is warranted, utilizing these analogues to establish
AI level for N-nitroso paroxetine is inadvisable.
Additional investigations are imperative to explore alternative methods
for assessing the safety of N-nitroso paroxetine.

sections.title: Limitations and Future Directions
sections.text:
While our study presented
a promising method for predicting the probability of metabolic α-carbon
hydroxylation of N-nitrosamines, there are several
limitations that should be considered when interpreting the outcomes
of this methodology.1.The developed model is only applicable
to nitrosamines that contain at least one α-CH2 group.
However, this limitation can potentially be addressed by creating
similar models for α-CH and α-CH3 groups by utilizing
xenobiotic metabolism data. This would allow us to expand the coverage
of NDSRIs and identify new features.2.While the model we developed represents
a significant improvement over relying solely on a small carcinogenic
nitrosamine database, it still identifies “uncovered features”
in some query nitrosamines, which can lead to unreliable predictions.
This is similar to the out-of-domain outcomes that are commonly encountered
in QSAR models and can be addressed by collecting and utilizing a
more extensive range of xenobiotic metabolism data to improve the
model’s coverage.3.Our study suggests that predicting
α-carbon hydroxylation alone may not be sufficient for accurately
assessing the carcinogenic potential of NDSRIs since we found little
overall correlation between predicted α-CH2 hydroxylation
and the TD50 values of the experimental test set. Other
factors, such as the reactivity of the resulting diazonium intermediate
and various alternative metabolic clearance routes, can significantly
impact their carcinogenic potency. These factors require careful scrutiny
in the risk assessment of NDSRIs.4.Furthermore, this approach may not
fully capture the metabolic chemistry unique to nitrosamines. Specifically,
our method does not consider any intramolecular rearrangements involving
the nitrosamine moiety that may occur during α-hydroxylation.
This limitation highlights the need for further research.5.The accuracy of our α-hydroxylation
prediction model is entirely reliant on the xenobiotic metabolism
data, particularly the substrate–metabolite pairs. Any spontaneous
rearrangement that obstructs the detection of the newly added OH group
or omission of reporting intermediate hydroxylation products may likely
impact the results. The developed model is only applicable
to nitrosamines that contain at least one α-CH2 group.
However, this limitation can potentially be addressed by creating
similar models for α-CH and α-CH3 groups by utilizing
xenobiotic metabolism data. This would allow us to expand the coverage
of NDSRIs and identify new features. While the model we developed represents
a significant improvement over relying solely on a small carcinogenic
nitrosamine database, it still identifies “uncovered features”
in some query nitrosamines, which can lead to unreliable predictions.
This is similar to the out-of-domain outcomes that are commonly encountered
in QSAR models and can be addressed by collecting and utilizing a
more extensive range of xenobiotic metabolism data to improve the
model’s coverage. Our study suggests that predicting
α-carbon hydroxylation alone may not be sufficient for accurately
assessing the carcinogenic potential of NDSRIs since we found little
overall correlation between predicted α-CH2 hydroxylation
and the TD50 values of the experimental test set. Other
factors, such as the reactivity of the resulting diazonium intermediate
and various alternative metabolic clearance routes, can significantly
impact their carcinogenic potency. These factors require careful scrutiny
in the risk assessment of NDSRIs. Furthermore, this approach may not
fully capture the metabolic chemistry unique to nitrosamines. Specifically,
our method does not consider any intramolecular rearrangements involving
the nitrosamine moiety that may occur during α-hydroxylation.
This limitation highlights the need for further research. The accuracy of our α-hydroxylation
prediction model is entirely reliant on the xenobiotic metabolism
data, particularly the substrate–metabolite pairs. Any spontaneous
rearrangement that obstructs the detection of the newly added OH group
or omission of reporting intermediate hydroxylation products may likely
impact the results.

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, we aimed to develop a method
for identifying and
quantifying the contributions of various structural features to the
metabolic hydroxylation of the α-CH2 groups of N-nitrosamines, a critical and rate-limiting step for these
compounds to become DNA reactive and eventually carcinogenic. To achieve
this, we utilized substrate–metabolite pairs of non-nitrosamine
xenobiotics to build models for CH2-hydroxylation and made
headway in addressing the challenge of limited animal carcinogenicity
data availability for assessing the carcinogenic potential of untested
nitrosamines. Our study revealed that the computed importance
of molecular fragments
around α-CH2 groups could be used to construct fingerprints
for nitrosamines, enabling effective clustering and identification
of key features that illuminate the SARs of α-carbon hydroxylation.
By expanding the set of statistically significant structural features
that may potentially affect the α-hydroxylation step, our study
enhances our ability to assess complex NDSRIs. It is worth noting
that our study showed little overall correlation
between predicted α-CH2 hydroxylation and the overall
TD50 for the experimental test set. This suggests that
predicting the α-carbon hydroxylation probability alone may
not be sufficient for accurately assessing the carcinogenic potential
of NDSRIs. However, we did find that the relative contributions of
molecular fragments related to α-carbon hydroxylation overlapped
with fragment contributions to nitrosamine carcinogenic potency despite
the lack of direct correlation between predicted α-carbon hydroxylation
probabilities and carcinogenic potency. This suggests that our approach
may provide a valuable complement to the read across method for predicting
the carcinogenic potential of NDSRIs. Also, comparison of prediction
performance of fragments of different lengths indicates that structural
features beyond 4 atoms offer no additional benefits, an important
consideration in developing SARs and analogue selection. Finally,
our study demonstrated that the small data set of nitrosamines
with available carcinogenicity data is insufficient to represent the
structural diversity of NDSRIs. However, by predicting α-carbon
hydroxylation, we can narrow down the list of analogues for establishing
daily AI limits, improving the accuracy and reliability of risk assessment
for nitrosamines. Overall, our study provides a promising framework
for advancing the risk assessment of nitrosamines.

full_text:
## Introduction
Nitrosamines are found in a variety of
sources including air, food,
water, tobacco, cosmetics, and packing materials.1−3 Due to their
potentially strong carcinogenic effects,4,5 the International
Council for Harmonisation (ICH) M7 guidance6 classifies N-nitrosamines as one of the three classes
of cohort-of-concern compounds. Consequently, the daily acceptable
intake (AI) of nitrosamines should be significantly lower than the
default threshold of toxicological concern (TTC) of 1.5 μg/day
for other mutagenic impurities. The discovery of N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) as an impurity in the drug valsartan
in 2018 sparked a heightened focus on controlling nitrosamine impurities
in the pharmaceutical industry,7 regulatory
agencies,8 and scientific community.9 In addition, detection of several API-derived
complex nitrosamines referred to as the nitrosamine drug substance
related impurities (NDSRIs) prompted the withdrawal of several drugs
from the market.10−13 Currently, regulators typically recommend a conservative AI of 18
ng/day for a novel NDSRI in cases where animal carcinogenicity data
are not available or when proper structurally related surrogates are
absent. However, the carcinogenic potency of nitrosamines varies considerably14−16 as indicated by the TD50 values derived from animal testing.
Thus, imposing a uniform limit of 18 ng/day for all nitrosamines may
not be necessary. Such a measure could have unintended economic consequences
for the pharmaceutical industry, potentially resulting in medication
shortages for the public. The absence of carcinogenicity testing
data creates a significant
challenge in evaluating complex nitrosamines, such as the NDSRIs.
According to a recent publication by Schlingemann et al.,17 nitrosamines are quite likely to be present
in drug substances with 40.4% of APIs and 29.6% of API impurities
having the potential to form these compounds. Despite available animal
carcinogenicity data for several small nitrosamines, they are often
not representative enough for the NDSRIs. Hence, the scientific community
must seek alternative methods to assess nitrosamines that lack or
have limited data. Various approaches in this regard can potentially
be employed, including alternative in vivo and in vitro18 assays as well as computational methods such
as (quantitative) structure–activity relationships ((Q)SARs).19,20 Specifically, structure–activity relationships (SARs) have
shown potential as regulatory agencies have utilized surrogate-based
SARs to establish AI levels for some nitrosamine impurities,21 and several SAR-based studies have recently
been published.22−24 Quantum chemical approaches have also been applied
to calculate the reactivity of N-nitrosamines as
demonstrated by Wenzel et al.25 and others.26−28 Despite the potential demonstrated by the surrogate-based
SAR methods,
their effectiveness is limited by the narrow structural diversity
of small nitrosamines, restricting their ability in evaluating carcinogenic
potential of the untested NDSRIs with diverse structures. Nonetheless,
some key structural features have been identified as contributing
to reduced carcinogenic potency, such as the presence of electron-withdrawing
substituents at the β-carbon, steric bulk at the α-carbon,
absence of α-carbon hydrogens, and carboxylic acid groups.23,24 Conversely, features known to increase potency include small alkyl
side chains, benzylic side chains, β-carbonyl groups, and allylic
or propargylic side chains.23 Thus, the
number of features discovered so far is small, and it remains uncertain
whether small nitrosamines can continue to be the only source of comprehensive
and reliable assessment of the carcinogenicity risk of the numerous
NDSRIs; a breakthrough is desperately needed. In this paper,
we present a novel method for predicting the likelihood
of α-carbon hydroxylation, one of the crucial steps in the metabolic
activation of nitrosamines leading to carcinogenicity. α-Hydroxylation
is the rate-limiting step in cytochrome P450 (CYP) mediated metabolic
activation of nitrosamines, forming a nitrosocarbinolamine species
that decomposes into a DNA-reactive electrophilic diazonium species.29−31 It is generally agreed that substituents that reduce the likelihood
of α-carbon hydroxylation on the N-nitrosamine
through electronic or steric effects tend to reduce carcinogenic potency.32 The European Medicines Agency (EMA) for example
considers nitrosamines containing an α-hydrogen capable of metabolic
activation to be potentially mutagenic and carcinogenic to humans,
with varying potencies based on the nature of the functional groups,
the specifics of metabolic activation, and repair efficiency and capacity.33 Our approach, based on the metabolism
of non-nitrosamine xenobiotics,
aims to identify key structural features influencing aliphatic carbon
hydroxylation. Using a large data set of non-nitrosamine xenobiotic
metabolism consisting of substrate–metabolite pairs of various
chemicals, drugs, and drug-like compounds, we employed computational
methods similar to those used for predicting xenobiotic sites of metabolism
(SOM).34−37 Specifically, we focused on the likelihood of hydroxylation of methylene
(-CH2-) groups, hypothesizing that structural features
affecting CH2 hydroxylation in xenobiotics would also affect
α-CH2 hydroxylation in nitrosamines as both processes
are mediated by CYP enzymes.30,38 We assumed that the
nitrosamine moiety would have a constant effect while other structural
features would exert relative modulation. Our modeling yielded numerous
statistically significant fragments affecting likelihood of hydroxylation,
which we used to create molecular fingerprints for grouping nitrosamines
and discovering novel SARs. Additionally, we used the computed α-carbon
hydroxylation probabilities to guide the selection of read-across
analogues that can potentially be used to establish daily AI limits
of NDSRIs. While the predicted values of α-hydroxylation
did not directly
exhibit a correlation with carcinogenicity of small nitrosamines,
as other factors may also influence it, this study identified several
highly valuable features and their effects. This work is significant
because it provides a more comprehensive evaluation of complex NDSRIs
by enabling the computation of the quantitative contributions of a
wider and expandable range of structural features. As a result, it
broadens our ability to evaluate complex NDSRIs and overcomes some
of the limitations of the prior studies.

## Data and Methods
We obtained xenobiotic metabolism
data from our in-house database at MultiCASE. This database contains
16,318 substrate–metabolite pairs with information on enzymes,
organs, and species, sourced from various publications.39,40 We narrowed down the data set to 620 pairs involving only CH2 hydroxylation (CH2 to CH–OH conversion).
The transformations were primarily mediated by cytochrome P450 (CYP)
enzymes. Each substrate–metabolite pair may contain multiple
CH2 groups, with some undergoing metabolic hydroxylation
while others do not (Figure 1a). In total, we used 3530 CH2 sites as individual
data points for developing models to predict CH2 hydroxylation.
It is important to note that the curated data set does not include
any instances of N-nitrosamines undergoing α-carbon
hydroxylation. Instead, we manually incorporated a term for the >N–N=O
moiety in the regression equation when applying it to N-nitrosamines (see below). Example of a xenobiotic substrate undergoing
metabolic hydroxylation
at a CH2 group, (a) CH2 group highlighted with
an orange circle is the active site, whereas the ones highlighted
with the gray circles are inactive CH2 sites, i.e., not
hydroxylated. (b) Molecular fragments generated from the local environment
(highlighted with red bonds) of the active CH2 site (C3—sp3 non-ring carbon, C2—sp2 non-ring carbon, CR3—sp3
carbon in a non-aromatic ring, CR2—sp2 carbon in a non-aromatic
ring, C3H3—sp3 non-ring carbon with three hydrogens, CR3H—sp3
carbon with one hydrogen in a non-aromatic ring, CR3H2—sp3
carbon with two hydrogens in a non-aromatic ring, and CR2H—sp2
carbon with one hydrogen in a non-aromatic ring). We collected a data
set of nitrosamines with animal carcinogenicity assay outcomes from
various sources, including the publication of Dobo et al.22 and data collected by MultiCASE. The data were
originally obtained from the Carcinogenic Potency Database by Gold
et al.41 and some other publications.42−44 Nitrosoureas, nitrosoguanidines, compounds with multiple nitrosamine
groups, and nitrosamines without any α-CH2 groups
were excluded, resulting in a final set of 84 compounds. The carcinogenic
potency was expressed as TD50 in units of mg/kg/day. We obtained a list of potential drug substance
related nitrosamines from Schlingemann et al.17 Structures of these NDSRIs were generated by Schlingemann et al.
from a large list of small drug and drug impurities. The original
list contained 9862 compounds, which were curated by removing duplicates,
neutralizing charges, correcting atom type errors, and removing compounds
with multiple nitrosamine groups or without α-CH2 groups. This resulted in a final set of 6277 nitrosamines. We encoded the local structural environments of
active and inactive CH2 groups of xenobiotics by generating
small molecular fragments with the CH2 group as the starting
point (Figure 1). Active
CH2 groups undergo hydroxylation in substrate–metabolite
pairs, whereas the inactive CH2 groups do not (Figure 1a). The generated
fragments were used as descriptors in model building. They were also
used to encode the structural environment of the α-CH2 groups in nitrosamines in the form of fingerprints (see below). The molecular fragment representations (Figure 1b) were produced using an algorithm modified
from one which is used for generating unique SMILES representation,45 resulting in a distinct textual representation.
This representation depicts atom attributes such as element type,
hybridization, aromaticity, number of attached hydrogens, and ring
memberships, providing a visually interpretable and information-rich
encoding of structural information beyond that of conventional SMILES.
For example, in the fragment [CR2](=[CR2H]-[CR3H2])-[CR3H2], CR2 represents
a sp2 carbon that lacks any hydrogens in a non-aromatic ring, CR2H
represents a sp2 carbon having one hydrogen in a non-aromatic ring,
and CR3H2 represents a sp3 carbon having two hydrogens in a non-aromatic
ring. We utilized a subset of 620 substrates from the xenobiotic database
to create a model to predict the likelihood of CYP-mediated hydroxylation
at CH2 sites. The model building process is depicted in Figure 2. Each CH2 group in a substrate–metabolite pair was considered a data
point, resulting in 3530 CH2 sites, with 839 active and
2691 inactive ones. Active CH2 groups were assigned a label
of 1, while inactive CH2 groups were labeled 0. These labels
are similar to the biological activity data (Y) in
a QSAR. The counts of fragment descriptors generated from the local
environment of each CH2 group were used in the X-matrix.
Any fragment that appeared in less than 5 CH2 groups was
removed to prevent overfitting. Process of building a model involves collecting m fragments from the structural environments of n CH2 groups from the xenobiotic training set.
Following
the variable selection process, m′ fragments
remain. The orange and green boxes in the Y-column indicate active
and inactive CH2 groups, respectively. The X-matrix comprises
counts of various fragments (frg1, frg2, etc.). During the regression fitting process,
the the regression coefficients (a1, a2, etc.)
and the regression constant are computed to derive
eq 1, Figure 2, which
essentially is the model. We also employed a variable selection process to
identify fragments
that are not relevant to CH2 hydroxylation. For example,
644 linear fragments up to 4 atoms long were initially generated from
the training set, but only 386 fragments survived the variable selection
process. The “R” package glmnet(46,47) was used for this purpose. It combines 10-fold cross-validation
with the logistic regression method and generates coefficients for
the fragments (a1, a2,...am’ in eq 1, Figure 2). In the resulting model, fragments with positive
coefficients were considered favorable for hydroxylation, while negative
coefficients were considered inhibitory. To predict metabolic hydroxylation
probability of a CH2 group in a query compound, fragments
around it are generated and matched with model fragments, and a probability
value is computed using eq 1, Figure 2. If any fragments are found outside of the training
set, they are classified as “uncovered fragments,” and
the outcome can be considered as out-of-domain. As the training
data set for xenobiotic metabolism does not include instances of N-nitrosamines undergoing α-carbon hydroxylation,
we manually added a term for the >N–N=O moiety to
eq
1, Figure 2, when applying
it to predict the α-hydroxylation of N-nitrosamines.
A high coefficient value of +2.00 was assigned to this term to ensure
that the nitrosamine moiety always has a constant positive effect
while other groups have a positive or negative modulatory impact on
the predicted probability. Moreover, this value yielded a satisfactory
distribution of calculated hydroxylation probabilities for nitrosamines,
preventing extreme values close to 0 or 1. It also counterbalances
the negative effects of xenobiotic amine-based fragments on hydroxylation.
The Supporting Information provides necessary details. Fingerprints
were needed for comparing and clustering nitrosamines based on their
structural features relevant to α-CH2 hydroxylation.
To do so, a vector containing the same number of slots as there were
fragments in the X-matrix of the model (i.e., 644) was created. Next,
each slot of this vector was filled with the corresponding regression
coefficients of the fragments from the prior step of modeling CH2-hydroxylation in xenobiotics. Molecular structure handling, curation, molecular
fragmentation, database operations, metabolism site detection, and
modeling were carried out using an in-house cheminformatics software
library. The cv.glmnet procedure was performed using
the “R” package glmnet.(46,47) Clustering was performed using the “R” package rtsne.(48) We have utilized the MultiCASE software QSAR Flex(21,49) to find appropriate analogues for NDSRIs in certain
cases.

## Xenobiotic Metabolism Data
We obtained xenobiotic metabolism
data from our in-house database at MultiCASE. This database contains
16,318 substrate–metabolite pairs with information on enzymes,
organs, and species, sourced from various publications.39,40 We narrowed down the data set to 620 pairs involving only CH2 hydroxylation (CH2 to CH–OH conversion).
The transformations were primarily mediated by cytochrome P450 (CYP)
enzymes. Each substrate–metabolite pair may contain multiple
CH2 groups, with some undergoing metabolic hydroxylation
while others do not (Figure 1a). In total, we used 3530 CH2 sites as individual
data points for developing models to predict CH2 hydroxylation.
It is important to note that the curated data set does not include
any instances of N-nitrosamines undergoing α-carbon
hydroxylation. Instead, we manually incorporated a term for the >N–N=O
moiety in the regression equation when applying it to N-nitrosamines (see below). Example of a xenobiotic substrate undergoing
metabolic hydroxylation
at a CH2 group, (a) CH2 group highlighted with
an orange circle is the active site, whereas the ones highlighted
with the gray circles are inactive CH2 sites, i.e., not
hydroxylated. (b) Molecular fragments generated from the local environment
(highlighted with red bonds) of the active CH2 site (C3—sp3 non-ring carbon, C2—sp2 non-ring carbon, CR3—sp3
carbon in a non-aromatic ring, CR2—sp2 carbon in a non-aromatic
ring, C3H3—sp3 non-ring carbon with three hydrogens, CR3H—sp3
carbon with one hydrogen in a non-aromatic ring, CR3H2—sp3
carbon with two hydrogens in a non-aromatic ring, and CR2H—sp2
carbon with one hydrogen in a non-aromatic ring).

## Nitrosamine Carcinogenicity Data
We collected a data
set of nitrosamines with animal carcinogenicity assay outcomes from
various sources, including the publication of Dobo et al.22 and data collected by MultiCASE. The data were
originally obtained from the Carcinogenic Potency Database by Gold
et al.41 and some other publications.42−44 Nitrosoureas, nitrosoguanidines, compounds with multiple nitrosamine
groups, and nitrosamines without any α-CH2 groups
were excluded, resulting in a final set of 84 compounds. The carcinogenic
potency was expressed as TD50 in units of mg/kg/day.

## NDSRIs
We obtained a list of potential drug substance
related nitrosamines from Schlingemann et al.17 Structures of these NDSRIs were generated by Schlingemann et al.
from a large list of small drug and drug impurities. The original
list contained 9862 compounds, which were curated by removing duplicates,
neutralizing charges, correcting atom type errors, and removing compounds
with multiple nitrosamine groups or without α-CH2 groups. This resulted in a final set of 6277 nitrosamines.

## Modeling

and CR3H2 represents a sp3 carbon having two hydrogens in a non-aromatic
ring. We utilized a subset of 620 substrates from the xenobiotic database
to create a model to predict the likelihood of CYP-mediated hydroxylation
at CH2 sites. The model building process is depicted in Figure 2. Each CH2 group in a substrate–metabolite pair was considered a data
point, resulting in 3530 CH2 sites, with 839 active and
2691 inactive ones. Active CH2 groups were assigned a label
of 1, while inactive CH2 groups were labeled 0. These labels
are similar to the biological activity data (Y) in
a QSAR. The counts of fragment descriptors generated from the local

Any fragment that appeared in less than 5 CH2 groups was

the the regression coefficients (a1, a2, etc.)
and the regression constant are computed to derive

process. The “R” package glmnet(46,47) was used for this purpose. It combines 10-fold cross-validation
with the logistic regression method and generates coefficients for
the fragments (a1, a2,...am’ in eq 1, Figure 2). In the resulting model, fragments with positive
coefficients were considered favorable for hydroxylation, while negative
coefficients were considered inhibitory. To predict metabolic hydroxylation
probability of a CH2 group in a query compound, fragments
around it are generated and matched with model fragments, and a probability
value is computed using eq 1, Figure 2. If any fragments are found outside of the training
set, they are classified as “uncovered fragments,” and
the outcome can be considered as out-of-domain. As the training
data set for xenobiotic metabolism does not include instances of N-nitrosamines undergoing α-carbon hydroxylation,
we manually added a term for the >N–N=O moiety to
eq
1, Figure 2, when applying
it to predict the α-hydroxylation of N-nitrosamines.
A high coefficient value of +2.00 was assigned to this term to ensure
that the nitrosamine moiety always has a constant positive effect
while other groups have a positive or negative modulatory impact on
the predicted probability. Moreover, this value yielded a satisfactory
distribution of calculated hydroxylation probabilities for nitrosamines,
preventing extreme values close to 0 or 1. It also counterbalances
the negative effects of xenobiotic amine-based fragments on hydroxylation.
The Supporting Information provides necessary details.

## Descriptors (Capturing Structural Environments of CH
We encoded the local structural environments of
active and inactive CH2 groups of xenobiotics by generating
small molecular fragments with the CH2 group as the starting
point (Figure 1). Active
CH2 groups undergo hydroxylation in substrate–metabolite
pairs, whereas the inactive CH2 groups do not (Figure 1a). The generated
fragments were used as descriptors in model building. They were also
used to encode the structural environment of the α-CH2 groups in nitrosamines in the form of fingerprints (see below). The molecular fragment representations (Figure 1b) were produced using an algorithm modified
from one which is used for generating unique SMILES representation,45 resulting in a distinct textual representation.
This representation depicts atom attributes such as element type,
hybridization, aromaticity, number of attached hydrogens, and ring
memberships, providing a visually interpretable and information-rich
encoding of structural information beyond that of conventional SMILES.
For example, in the fragment [CR2](=[CR2H]-[CR3H2])-[CR3H2], CR2 represents
a sp2 carbon that lacks any hydrogens in a non-aromatic ring, CR2H
represents a sp2 carbon having one hydrogen in a non-aromatic ring,
and CR3H2 represents a sp3 carbon having two hydrogens in a non-aromatic
ring.

## Building Model for CH
We utilized a subset of 620 substrates from the xenobiotic database
to create a model to predict the likelihood of CYP-mediated hydroxylation
at CH2 sites. The model building process is depicted in Figure 2. Each CH2 group in a substrate–metabolite pair was considered a data
point, resulting in 3530 CH2 sites, with 839 active and
2691 inactive ones. Active CH2 groups were assigned a label
of 1, while inactive CH2 groups were labeled 0. These labels
are similar to the biological activity data (Y) in
a QSAR. The counts of fragment descriptors generated from the local
environment of each CH2 group were used in the X-matrix.
Any fragment that appeared in less than 5 CH2 groups was
removed to prevent overfitting. Process of building a model involves collecting m fragments from the structural environments of n CH2 groups from the xenobiotic training set.
Following
the variable selection process, m′ fragments
remain. The orange and green boxes in the Y-column indicate active
and inactive CH2 groups, respectively. The X-matrix comprises
counts of various fragments (frg1, frg2, etc.). During the regression fitting process,
the the regression coefficients (a1, a2, etc.)
and the regression constant are computed to derive
eq 1, Figure 2, which
essentially is the model. We also employed a variable selection process to
identify fragments
that are not relevant to CH2 hydroxylation. For example,
644 linear fragments up to 4 atoms long were initially generated from
the training set, but only 386 fragments survived the variable selection
process. The “R” package glmnet(46,47) was used for this purpose. It combines 10-fold cross-validation
with the logistic regression method and generates coefficients for
the fragments (a1, a2,...am’ in eq 1, Figure 2). In the resulting model, fragments with positive
coefficients were considered favorable for hydroxylation, while negative
coefficients were considered inhibitory.

## Making Predictions
To predict metabolic hydroxylation
probability of a CH2 group in a query compound, fragments
around it are generated and matched with model fragments, and a probability
value is computed using eq 1, Figure 2. If any fragments are found outside of the training
set, they are classified as “uncovered fragments,” and
the outcome can be considered as out-of-domain. As the training
data set for xenobiotic metabolism does not include instances of N-nitrosamines undergoing α-carbon hydroxylation,
we manually added a term for the >N–N=O moiety to
eq
1, Figure 2, when applying
it to predict the α-hydroxylation of N-nitrosamines.
A high coefficient value of +2.00 was assigned to this term to ensure
that the nitrosamine moiety always has a constant positive effect
while other groups have a positive or negative modulatory impact on
the predicted probability. Moreover, this value yielded a satisfactory
distribution of calculated hydroxylation probabilities for nitrosamines,
preventing extreme values close to 0 or 1. It also counterbalances
the negative effects of xenobiotic amine-based fragments on hydroxylation.
The Supporting Information provides necessary details.

## Building Fingerprints for Nitrosamines
Fingerprints
were needed for comparing and clustering nitrosamines based on their
structural features relevant to α-CH2 hydroxylation.
To do so, a vector containing the same number of slots as there were
fragments in the X-matrix of the model (i.e., 644) was created. Next,
each slot of this vector was filled with the corresponding regression
coefficients of the fragments from the prior step of modeling CH2-hydroxylation in xenobiotics.

## Software
Molecular structure handling, curation, molecular
fragmentation, database operations, metabolism site detection, and
modeling were carried out using an in-house cheminformatics software
library. The cv.glmnet procedure was performed using
the “R” package glmnet.(46,47) Clustering was performed using the “R” package rtsne.(48) We have utilized the MultiCASE software QSAR Flex(21,49) to find appropriate analogues for NDSRIs in certain
cases.

NDSRIs, while only 51 were shared with the small nitrosamines. We
employed the 4-atom linear fragments specifying ring atoms of 8 or
smaller sized rings as determined from the CV exercise. The Supporting
Information contains both a comprehensive list of all the fragments
with their corresponding regression coefficients and a compilation
of the top fragments.

## Assessing α-CH
The regression coefficients
for the fragments relevant to CH2 hydroxylation can be
utilized to generate fingerprints to represent the structural environments
of the >N–N=O moiety. We utilized the NDSRIs for
generating
a large set of cyclic and acyclic nitrosamine motifs, fingerprints
of which were then used for clustering to uncover potential SARs.
To ensure independent evaluation of the effects of various features
on the α-CH2 group, we replaced each side chain of
an acyclic NDSRI with a −CH3 group, one at a time,
producing compounds with only one chain containing a α-CH2 group. The cyclic nitrosamines were not altered. This resulted
in a data set of 1690 acyclic and 1009 cyclic nitrosamines after excluding
nitrosamines with uncovered fragments. The nitrosamines were clustered
using tSNE methodology and color-coded based on their hydroxylation
probability (Figures 5 and 6). Tables 1 and 2 list some of
the representative structural motifs and their hydroxylation probabilities. Clusters
of acyclic nitrosamine motifs containing only one α-CH2 with the hydroxylation probability indicated by the color
coding. Clusters of cyclic nitrosamine motifs with the α-hydroxylation
probability indicated by the color coding. Highest hydroxylation probability
is taken if two α-CH2 sites exist. Furthermore, we computed α-CH2 hydroxylation
probabilities
for nitrosamines with various features identified as important by
domain experts23 in published articles.
The main objective was to determine if the computed probabilities
align with the current SAR knowledge. The results are shown in Table 3. Interestingly, the
computed values concurred with expert deductions, except for the impact
of the β-carbonyl group. We confirmed the deactivating effect
of the carboxylic acid group19 in the side
chain within a distance of 4 atoms and observed the boosting effects
of the benzyl, allyl, and small alkyl chains, which validates expert
opinions. The hydroxylation value of the β-carbonyl group was
lower because of fewer active CH2 groups compared to inactive
CH2 groups adjacent to carbonyl groups in the xenobiotic
substrates. We were unable to compute values for some features due
to uncovered fragments, e.g., strong electron withdrawing −CF3 group. Such data gaps could potentially be filled by expanding
the xenobiotic metabolism data set in the future. Feature exists in xenobiotics next
to a CH2 group without a N-nitroso group. Feature exists in NDSRIs next
to
a CH2 group which is “alpha” to a N-nitroso group. Nonetheless, the clustering exercise (refer to Figures 5 and 6) yielded very valuable information on the quantitative effects
of
a significantly greater number of NDSRI features than those identified
by experts to date.23,24 It also provides useful structure–activity
relations, for example as shown in Table 1, varying effects of aromatic rings at β
position, a benzylic side chain (cluster #6) yields a probability
of 0.55, but the 3-methylene pyridine version has a slightly lower
probability (0.49, cluster #8), whereas, the 2-methylene thiophene
and the 2-methylene pyridine give significantly higher values of 0.81
(cluster #1) and 0.82 (cluster #2), respectively. Similarly as shown
in Table 2, various
features for cyclic nitrosamines were also identified. For example,
presence of an aromatic ring within a distance of 1, 2, or 3 atoms
from the >N–N=O moiety increases the probability
of
α-hydroxylation (clusters #1 and 3–5), whereas, substitution
on the α-position on any side decreases the probability, e.g.,
clusters #6 and 7. This observation corroborates previous publications
that steric hindrance on the α-carbon inhibits the metabolic
activation of nitrosamines.23,24,50 Additionally, presence of a nitrogen in the ring at the 3-position
decreases the probability of α-hydroxylation. This can be observed
in clusters #8 and 9.

## Identifying Common Structural Features That Contribute to Both
α-Hydroxylation and Carcinogenic Potency
To further
explore the relationship between carcinogenic potency and α-hydroxylation,
we built a QSAR model directly using the carcinogenic potencies (−Log
TD50) of 84 small nitrosamines and fragments around their
α-CH2 groups as descriptors. As a result, 15 fragments
were identified that positively or negatively affect carcinogenicity
potency and we compared their regression coefficients to those obtained
from modeling xenobiotic CH2 hydroxylation. Table 4 shows that out of the 15 fragments,
14 were also found in the xenobiotic data set. Interestingly, three
fragments with positive effects on carcinogenicity also had a positive
effect on xenobiotic CH2 hydroxylation and four with negative
influence on carcinogenicity had a negative effect on xenobiotic CH2 hydroxylation too. Particularly noteworthy is the fragment
[C3H2]-[N3]-[C3H3], which demonstrated conflicting contributions.
While being part of the >N–N=O moiety of methyl nitrosamines
in the carcinogenicity data set led to its expected positive contribution
toward carcinogenicity, it had a negative coefficient in xenobiotic
hydroxylation because of being a part of tertiary amines that apparently
exert a negative effect on CH2-hydroxylation. Despite the
limited size of the nitrosamine data set, our findings provide compelling
evidence that certain structural features that modulate CH2 hydroxylation in xenobiotics also have similar effects on the carcinogenic
potency of nitrosamines. The CH2 site is highlighted
in red.

## Analogue Selection To Establish Daily AI Limits
Establishing
AI limits for complex N-nitrosamines in the absence
of animal carcinogenicity data poses a critical challenge.23 While read-across using analogues is a common
practice,21 selecting a single analogue
for AI elucidation remains difficult. It is therefore important to
perform a critical analysis of the analogues’ structural features
in relation to the query as molecular similarity measures alone are
insufficient. The predictive model built in this study is a
valuable tool for identifying small analogues by comparing their α-hydroxylation
potential to the query N-nitrosamine. Also, structural
fragments that are pertinent to α-hydroxylation can be used
to assess the reliability of these analogues as “uncovered
fragments” in close proximity to the nitrosamine moiety of
the analogues or absence of crucial fragments relative to the query
nitrosamine should be deemed less reliable and consequently can be
considered for exclusion. The methodology is demonstrated through
some examples below, highlighting
the importance of careful selection of analogues for the establishment
of AI limits for complex N-nitrosamines. In this study,
we applied the calculation of the likelihood of α-hydroxylation
to the N-nitroso derivative of varenicline and three
related N-nitrosamine analogues (NPIP, NHEX, and
NTHP) with available carcinogenicity data (Figure 8). The analogues are taken from a recent
publication by Ponting et al.23 The predicted
hydroxylation values for N-nitroso varenicline, NPIP,
and NHEX were 0.63, 0.56, and 0.56, respectively. Notably, the hydroxylation
values for NPIP and NHEX were identical despite their differing ring
sizes due to our modeling process treating rings of size 5–8
equally. Application of α-hydroxylation computation on N-nitroso varenicline and its structurally similar analogues for establishing
a daily AI limit. α-CH2 groups are shown with orange
circles (Pα-hydrox—computed probability of α-hydroxylation
and NC—not calculated due to the presence of uncovered fragments). The AI limit for N-nitroso varenicline
has been
set at 37 ng/day by several regulatory agencies, who have used NTHP
as a surrogate to determine the appropriate threshold.53−55 However, the α-hydroxylation value for NTHP could not be reliably
calculated due to the presence of “uncovered fragments”
near the nitrosamine moiety resulting from the presence of unsaturation
in the ring, indicating its structural dissimilarity to N-nitroso varenicline, NPIP, and NHEX. Conversely, NPIP and NHEX exhibited
hydroxylation values comparable to N-nitroso varenicline
and are deemed suitable surrogates for deriving the AI limit, consistent
with the opinion of Ponting et al. As a conservative measure, we can
select NHEX as the surrogate for AI derivation. According to Ponting
et al.,23 the AI limit was established
as 110 ng/day using the TD50 of NHEX from the most sensitive
tumorigenic site (TD50 = 0.110 mg/kg/day). In this study,
we aimed to assess the potential carcinogenicity of N-nitroso nortriptyline by comparing its α-hydroxylation potential
with that of the three structurally related analogues identified by
the QSAR Flex software program (Figure 9). QSAR Flex utilizes a database of small nitrosamines with carcinogenicity data
to match different atom types around the nitrosamine moiety for identifying
suitable analogues. Application of α-hydroxylation computation on N-nitroso nortriptyline and its structurally similar analogues.
α-CH2 groups are shown with orange circles (Pα-hydrox—computed
probability of α-hydroxylation). It is noteworthy that several regulatory agencies,
including Health
Canada55 and the EMA,54 have established an extremely low AI limit of 8 ng/day
for N-nitroso nortriptyline based on the TD50 of 0.008 mg/kg/day for N-nitroso methylphenethyl
amine. However, our findings raise a question about the appropriateness
of such a low AI limit for this particular NDSRI, given its relatively
low α-hydroxylation value of only 0.07, in comparison to the
higher values observed for the three analogues, including N-nitroso methylphenethyl amine. Despite experimental
evidence indicating that the primary clearance pathway for the selective
serotonin reuptake inhibitor paroxetine involves metabolic modification
of the 1,3-benzdioxole ring and that no metabolites resulting from
α-carbon hydroxylation after a possible nitrosation of the piperidine
ring were observed in humans,23 we conducted
this case study to evaluate the potential carcinogenicity of N-nitroso paroxetine to account for the theoretical possibility
of its introduction via external sources, e.g., as an impurity. Specifically,
we aimed to compare its α-hydroxylation potential with that
of three structurally related analogues (Figure 10). Application of α-hydroxylation computation
on N-nitroso paroxetine and its structurally similar
analogues. α-CH2 groups are shown with orange circles
(Pα-hydrox—computed
probability of α-hydroxylation). Our results revealed that N-nitroso
paroxetine
exhibited a significantly higher α-hydroxylation potential of
0.86 than two of its analogues, nitrosopiperdinol (0.61) and nitrosopiperidine
(0.56). Conversely, 1-nitroso-3-pyrrolidinol, the third analogue,
demonstrated a slightly higher hydroxylation potential (0.78) than
the other two analogues; however, its 5-membered ring structure, which
is more constrained, may explain its higher TD50 value.
Given the potential risks associated with nitrosamine impurities where
utmost caution is warranted, utilizing these analogues to establish
AI level for N-nitroso paroxetine is inadvisable.
Additional investigations are imperative to explore alternative methods
for assessing the safety of N-nitroso paroxetine.

## None
Despite experimental
evidence indicating that the primary clearance pathway for the selective
serotonin reuptake inhibitor paroxetine involves metabolic modification
of the 1,3-benzdioxole ring and that no metabolites resulting from
α-carbon hydroxylation after a possible nitrosation of the piperidine
ring were observed in humans,23 we conducted
this case study to evaluate the potential carcinogenicity of N-nitroso paroxetine to account for the theoretical possibility
of its introduction via external sources, e.g., as an impurity. Specifically,
we aimed to compare its α-hydroxylation potential with that
of three structurally related analogues (Figure 10). Application of α-hydroxylation computation
on N-nitroso paroxetine and its structurally similar
analogues. α-CH2 groups are shown with orange circles
(Pα-hydrox—computed
probability of α-hydroxylation). Our results revealed that N-nitroso
paroxetine
exhibited a significantly higher α-hydroxylation potential of
0.86 than two of its analogues, nitrosopiperdinol (0.61) and nitrosopiperidine
(0.56). Conversely, 1-nitroso-3-pyrrolidinol, the third analogue,
demonstrated a slightly higher hydroxylation potential (0.78) than
the other two analogues; however, its 5-membered ring structure, which
is more constrained, may explain its higher TD50 value.
Given the potential risks associated with nitrosamine impurities where
utmost caution is warranted, utilizing these analogues to establish
AI level for N-nitroso paroxetine is inadvisable.
Additional investigations are imperative to explore alternative methods
for assessing the safety of N-nitroso paroxetine.

## Limitations and Future Directions
While our study presented
a promising method for predicting the probability of metabolic α-carbon
hydroxylation of N-nitrosamines, there are several
limitations that should be considered when interpreting the outcomes
of this methodology.1.The developed model is only applicable
to nitrosamines that contain at least one α-CH2 group.
However, this limitation can potentially be addressed by creating
similar models for α-CH and α-CH3 groups by utilizing
xenobiotic metabolism data. This would allow us to expand the coverage
of NDSRIs and identify new features.2.While the model we developed represents
a significant improvement over relying solely on a small carcinogenic
nitrosamine database, it still identifies “uncovered features”
in some query nitrosamines, which can lead to unreliable predictions.
This is similar to the out-of-domain outcomes that are commonly encountered
in QSAR models and can be addressed by collecting and utilizing a
more extensive range of xenobiotic metabolism data to improve the
model’s coverage.3.Our study suggests that predicting
α-carbon hydroxylation alone may not be sufficient for accurately
assessing the carcinogenic potential of NDSRIs since we found little
overall correlation between predicted α-CH2 hydroxylation
and the TD50 values of the experimental test set. Other
factors, such as the reactivity of the resulting diazonium intermediate
and various alternative metabolic clearance routes, can significantly
impact their carcinogenic potency. These factors require careful scrutiny
in the risk assessment of NDSRIs.4.Furthermore, this approach may not
fully capture the metabolic chemistry unique to nitrosamines. Specifically,
our method does not consider any intramolecular rearrangements involving
the nitrosamine moiety that may occur during α-hydroxylation.
This limitation highlights the need for further research.5.The accuracy of our α-hydroxylation
prediction model is entirely reliant on the xenobiotic metabolism
data, particularly the substrate–metabolite pairs. Any spontaneous
rearrangement that obstructs the detection of the newly added OH group
or omission of reporting intermediate hydroxylation products may likely
impact the results. The developed model is only applicable
to nitrosamines that contain at least one α-CH2 group.
However, this limitation can potentially be addressed by creating
similar models for α-CH and α-CH3 groups by utilizing
xenobiotic metabolism data. This would allow us to expand the coverage
of NDSRIs and identify new features. While the model we developed represents
a significant improvement over relying solely on a small carcinogenic

in some query nitrosamines, which can lead to unreliable predictions.
This is similar to the out-of-domain outcomes that are commonly encountered

model’s coverage. Our study suggests that predicting

and the TD50 values of the experimental test set. Other
factors, such as the reactivity of the resulting diazonium intermediate

in the risk assessment of NDSRIs. Furthermore, this approach may not
fully capture the metabolic chemistry unique to nitrosamines. Specifically,
our method does not consider any intramolecular rearrangements involving
the nitrosamine moiety that may occur during α-hydroxylation.
This limitation highlights the need for further research. The accuracy of our α-hydroxylation
prediction model is entirely reliant on the xenobiotic metabolism
data, particularly the substrate–metabolite pairs. Any spontaneous
rearrangement that obstructs the detection of the newly added OH group
or omission of reporting intermediate hydroxylation products may likely
impact the results.

## Conclusions
In this study, we aimed to develop a method
for identifying and
quantifying the contributions of various structural features to the
metabolic hydroxylation of the α-CH2 groups of N-nitrosamines, a critical and rate-limiting step for these
compounds to become DNA reactive and eventually carcinogenic. To achieve
this, we utilized substrate–metabolite pairs of non-nitrosamine
xenobiotics to build models for CH2-hydroxylation and made
headway in addressing the challenge of limited animal carcinogenicity
data availability for assessing the carcinogenic potential of untested
nitrosamines. Our study revealed that the computed importance
of molecular fragments
around α-CH2 groups could be used to construct fingerprints
for nitrosamines, enabling effective clustering and identification
of key features that illuminate the SARs of α-carbon hydroxylation.
By expanding the set of statistically significant structural features
that may potentially affect the α-hydroxylation step, our study
enhances our ability to assess complex NDSRIs. It is worth noting
that our study showed little overall correlation
between predicted α-CH2 hydroxylation and the overall
TD50 for the experimental test set. This suggests that
predicting the α-carbon hydroxylation probability alone may
not be sufficient for accurately assessing the carcinogenic potential
of NDSRIs. However, we did find that the relative contributions of
molecular fragments related to α-carbon hydroxylation overlapped
with fragment contributions to nitrosamine carcinogenic potency despite
the lack of direct correlation between predicted α-carbon hydroxylation
probabilities and carcinogenic potency. This suggests that our approach
may provide a valuable complement to the read across method for predicting
the carcinogenic potential of NDSRIs. Also, comparison of prediction
performance of fragments of different lengths indicates that structural
features beyond 4 atoms offer no additional benefits, an important
consideration in developing SARs and analogue selection. Finally,
our study demonstrated that the small data set of nitrosamines
with available carcinogenicity data is insufficient to represent the
structural diversity of NDSRIs. However, by predicting α-carbon
hydroxylation, we can narrow down the list of analogues for establishing
daily AI limits, improving the accuracy and reliability of risk assessment
for nitrosamines. Overall, our study provides a promising framework
for advancing the risk assessment of nitrosamines.
